fields.headline: Incognito review – 'a complex, restless narrative'
fields.bodyText: We need more playwrights like Nick Payne. He is that rare thing: a writer whose substantial ambitions are matched by an acute understanding of the way people actually behave. His 2012 play Constellations was a runaway success, taking its examination of love and quantum physics from London's Royal Court to the West End, and scoring a clutch of award nominations. Blurred Lines, staged in January in the National Theatre's Shed, proved a complete change of tack: an explosive examination of gender politics, performed by an all-female cast. With Incognito, premiering at the HighTide Festival theatre – that powerhouse of new writing whose annual festival brings a roster of high-quality theatre to Suffolk – and co-produced by the excellent young company Nabokov, Payne returns to his central preoccupation with science. Taking neuroscience as his theme, he tells three interconnected stories – that of Thomas Stoltz Harvey, the pathologist who, in 1955, stole Albert Einstein's brain for private study; Henry, a patient undergoing pioneering brain surgery in Bath in 1953; and Martha, a neuropsychologist in contemporary London attempting to make sense of her present and her past. The complex, restless narrative unfolds in a series of brief, fragmented scenes, performed with lightning-fast reflexes by the superb cast of four, who are required to swap characters (and accents) with split-second accuracy. The effect is sometimes bewildering – I advise carefully studying the synopsis first – and Payne could have thought harder about how to ensure his audience can always keep up with his rapid-fire sequence of ideas. But this is an intelligent, ambitious work that poses as many questions as it answers – much like the human brain itself.
